unit_learning_outcomes.description: explain foundational concepts in electricity and magnetism, and describe them in terms of concise mathematical models.
clearly explain physics concepts learned and illustrate these to peers.
demonstrate foundational learning skills including active engagement in your learning process
analyse linear electrical circuits through the use of appropriate models including circuit simplifications, mesh and node analysis, and equivalent circuits.
build and model simple electrical circuits and measure circuit properties with a digital multi-meter.
perform and report on laboratory experiments using a broad range of equipment, with an increased sophistication in treatment of errors.

non_scheduled_learning_activities.description: Consolidating lecture content and preparing for SGTAs, using lecture material, textbook, and iLearn resources.

assessments.description: You are required to maintain a well-organised physical or electronic notebook in which you write notes, complete tutorial questions, and record other work showing evidence of engagement with the unit. This will be assessed each week during the SGTA session. The purpose of this assessment task is to encourage your consistent engagement with the unit throughout the session.
Examination in the university exam period, covering the entire content from the unit.
Assessment of in-lab record of experimental activities, as well as any pre-lab work.
Assignments for problem solving and exploring physics concepts.

data.subject_search_title: PHYS1520 - Physics for Electrical and Electronic Engineering
data.description: This unit, following on from PHYS1510 completes the overview of electric and magnetic physics required for further study in electrical and electronic engineering disciplines. We complete the theory of electromagnetism, studying fields, potentials, the origin and effects of magnetic fields and electromagnetic induction, all described by Maxwell's equations. We link this physics to the fundamental quantities used in circuit theory: emf, voltage, current, resistance, capacitance, and inductance. We develop the language and toolkit used to design and analyse simple circuits, including the circuit theorems and circuit analysis techniques, and provide an introduction to electromagnetic radiation (light). Laboratory sessions provide a practical context for students to consolidate key concepts via conducting experiments  and carrying out open ended exploration of basic circuits.
data.search_title: PHYS1520 - Physics for Electrical and Electronic Engineering

We link this physics to the fundamental quantities used in circuit theory: emf, voltage, current, resistance, capacitance, and inductance. We develop the language and toolkit used to design and analyse simple circuits, including the circuit theorems and circuit analysis techniques, and provide an introduction to electromagnetic radiation (light). Laboratory sessions provide a practical context for students to consolidate key concepts via conducting experiments  and carrying out open ended exploration of basic circuits.
